repnme.cdata!: India - Uttar Pradesh Sector Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts, in addition to an unsatisfactory
            borrower performance; yet, the Bank performance is rated
            satisfactory, despite several constraints to support power
            sector restructuring in the State of Uttar Pradesh, India.
            Lessons first suggest that the scope and nature of reforms,
            pursued under a loan should be consistent with the lending
            instrument, and firmly grounded in a realistic appreciation
            of the Bank's relative leverage in a given situation.
            This operation was an investment loan in which, by
            definition, disbursements were determined by contract
            implementation, and as such, ill-suited to serve as drivers
            of a contentious and challenging reform program. Reform
            expectations in this case were unrealistically high given
            the relatively short period of project implementation, and
            even more so relative to the Bank's limited
            contribution to the utility's overall investment
            program. Second, assessments of "reform readiness"
            and "political commitment" are necessary, but not
            sufficient to guarantee implementation of complex reforms. A
            possible response is to require more upfront reform actions
            before commencing the project. Another approach relates to
            the first lesson cited above: a more appropriate link
            between the reform objectives, and the lending instrument
            would help avoid the inconsistency, and tension between
            reform implementation and implementation of physical
            investments, inherent in operations structured along the
            lines of this project. It is appropriate to note the
            consultations held between the Bank, the Government, and
            reforming states in 2003 on lessons from early reform
            experiences. The consultations, which have been reflected in
            the new Country Assistance Strategy (CAS), focused on how to
            identify key prerequisites for reform; how to design reform
            processes with credible approaches to inevitable political
            issues; and, how the Bank might rethink its rules of
            engagement to maximize the value of its support to India.
            While, in a sense, these lessons have already been learned,
            they were significantly informed by the Uttar Pradesh (UP) experience.
